newsitem.title: GERMANY: German commentators call Chirac decision risky.
newsitem.headline: German commentators call Chirac decision risky.

text.p: German press commentators on Monday called French President Jacques Chirac's decision to call an early parliamentary election to prepare for Europe's planned monetary union a risky strategy, but said it could pay off.
"Chirac's step contains chances, but also risks," wrote the daily Die Welt.

"A victory for the socialists and linked left-wing parties would mean a state legitimacy crisis could hardly be avoided and European policies, which are Chirac's priority, would then be seriously burdened."
But Die Welt said a victory would strengthen Chirac's personal position as president.
Chirac announced on Monday he was dissolving the National Assembly and called an early parliamentary election for May 25 and June 1 to prepare France for a single European currency.
The Berliner Morgenpost daily said dissolving parliament was no "cure-all".
"Chirac's team must first win the planned election (which is everything but certain), before they can demand new savings sacrifices from the French for the euro, with new legitimacy."
Chancellor Helmut Kohl reaffirmed Germany's commitment to the euro earlier this month by announcing -- also far ahead of schedule -- that he would run for re-election in late 1998.

Bonn's daily General Anzeiger called Chirac's decision a leap into the unknown, but said if he succeeded he would gain weight in the decisive phase leading up to the introduction of the euro and the reform of European institutions.
